claim:
Consider the following background information: A 62-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room with severe substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea. Imaging reveals transmural myocardial infarction in the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: The right main coronary artery is most likely occluded in this patient.

supporting.text: The right coronary artery supplies blood to the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum, making it the most likely site of occlusion in this case.

attacks.text: The right coronary artery supplies blood to the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum, making it the most likely site of occlusion in this case.
In some individuals, the left circumflex artery may supply the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum due to anatomical variation, making RCA occlusion less likely.
Coronary dominance patterns (right vs. left) significantly influence which artery supplies the posterior septum, and RCA dominance is not universal.
Acute occlusion of the RCA typically presents with inferior wall MI rather than isolated septal involvement, suggesting another vessel may be responsible.
Posterior septal MI from RCA occlusion is well-documented in right-dominant circulation, which accounts for ~85% of the population.

supporting.text: Transmural myocardial infarction in the posterior ventricular septum is typically caused by occlusion of the right coronary artery.

attacks.text: Transmural myocardial infarction in the posterior ventricular septum is typically caused by occlusion of the right coronary artery.
In some anatomical variations, the posterior ventricular septum may be supplied by the left circumflex artery rather than the right coronary artery.
Such anatomical variations are rare, occurring in less than 10% of the population, making the right coronary artery the statistically dominant cause.
The posterior descending artery (PDA) can also originate from the left coronary system in left-dominant or codominant circulation patterns.
Left-dominant circulation occurs in only about 15% of cases, while right-dominant circulation (where the RCA supplies the PDA) is present in approximately 70% of individuals.

supporting.text: The clinical presentation and imaging findings are consistent with a right coronary artery occlusion, as it is the primary blood supply to the posterior septum.

attacks.text: The clinical presentation and imaging findings are consistent with a right coronary artery occlusion, as it is the primary blood supply to the posterior septum.
While the right coronary artery is the most common blood supply to the posterior septum, anatomical variations exist where the left circumflex artery may supply this region instead.
The prevalence of left circumflex dominance is only about 15-20%, making right coronary artery occlusion still the most likely scenario.
The patient's symptoms could also be caused by a left main coronary artery occlusion, which can present similarly but is more life-threatening.
Left main occlusion typically presents with more extensive ECG changes and cardiogenic shock, which are not described in this case.

supporting.text: In most individuals, the right coronary artery is dominant and supplies the posterior descending artery, which perfuses the posterior ventricular septum.

attacks.text: In most individuals, the right coronary artery is dominant and supplies the posterior descending artery, which perfuses the posterior ventricular septum.
In approximately 15% of individuals, the left coronary artery is dominant and supplies the posterior descending artery instead of the right coronary artery.
Even in left-dominant circulation, the right coronary artery may still contribute to perfusion of the posterior ventricular septum through collateral circulation.
The patient's symptoms and imaging findings could also be caused by occlusion of a dominant left circumflex artery, which can supply the posterior ventricular septum.
Statistical data shows right coronary artery occlusion accounts for over 80% of posterior myocardial infarctions in right-dominant circulation systems.

supporting.text: The combination of substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea with posterior septal infarction strongly suggests right coronary artery occlusion.

attacks.text: The combination of substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea with posterior septal infarction strongly suggests right coronary artery occlusion.
Posterior septal infarctions can also be caused by occlusion of the left circumflex artery, which supplies the posterior septum in some individuals.
The right coronary artery is the dominant vessel in 85% of individuals and is more commonly responsible for posterior septal infarctions.
The patient's symptoms (diaphoresis, nausea) are non-specific and can occur with infarctions in any coronary artery territory.
While symptoms are non-specific, the combination with posterior septal infarction makes right coronary artery occlusion the most likely diagnosis statistically.
